If therapists are to avoid being experienced by the patient as an  "impinging object," as with the spatula, it is important that they  should be ready to wait for relating and understanding to emerge  in the patient's own time. This includes waiting for the transference  to develop

To that end the therapist tries to keep himself (as a  person) as little in evidence as can be in keeping with this aim of  preserving the therapeutic space, as neutral and therefore free to  be used in whatever way belongs to the therapeutic needs of the  patient.
A PATIENT'S USE OF THE THERAPIST'S AVAILABILITY

He therefore does not focus the patient's  anxiety immediately upon himsel~ that would be preemptive. Instead,  he leaves room for the patient to make her own reference to him, if  she is ready for this. It is all too easy to cut across a patient's spontaneous finding of  the therapist's presence by intervening too quickly

A similar error  is to bring the patient's communications to a premature focus onto  the therapist, which is often done in the name of transference. This  deadens the experience by lessening the sense ofimmedi2ey in the  transference.

Neither therapist  nor patient alone can know what is best or what is needed. This is  jointly discovered as the therapeutic process unfolds.
